docs.lead_paragraph: The National Academy of Sciences said the cost of any new benefits that must be provided by insurance plans under the health care overhaul should be “offset by savings” elsewhere.

headline.seo: Panel Says U.S. Should Weigh Cost in Health Coverage
headline.main: Panel Says U.S. Should Weigh Cost in Deciding ‘Essential Health Benefits’
headline.print_headline: Panel Says U.S. Should Weigh Cost in Deciding ‘Essential Health Benefits’

docs.snippet: The National Academy of Sciences said the cost of any new benefits that must be provided by insurance plans under the health care overhaul should be “offset by savings” elsewhere.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: As President Obama urges Congress to act on renewing an extension to unemployment benefits, some are arguing that it’s a hindrance to the economy and discourages workers.

headline.seo: Some Unemployed Find Fault in Extension of Jobless Benefits
headline.main: Some Unemployed Find Fault in Extension of Jobless Benefits
headline.print_headline: Some Unemployed Find Fault In Extension of Jobless Benefits

docs.snippet: As President Obama urges Congress to act on renewing an extension to unemployment benefits, some are arguing that it’s a hindrance to the economy and discourages workers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Malpractice reform, if it is done right, is a good thing, but it is best addressed outside the deficit-reduction framework.

docs.lead_paragraph: As health care costs rise, some providers are experimenting with new payment and care delivery systems, striving to be efficient and to keep patients well.

headline.main: Trying Out New Ways to Deliver Health Care
headline.print_headline: Trying Out New Ways To Deliver Health Care

docs.snippet: As health care costs rise, some providers are experimenting with new payment and care delivery systems, striving to be efficient and to keep patients well.

docs.lead_paragraph: News that an influential panel of experts is advising healthy men not to be screened for prostate cancer with a widely used test is certain to cause confusion and anxiety among men and their doctors, and reignites a debate about the benefits and risks of screening tests. The recommendations, to be officially announced on Tuesday by the United States Preventive Services Task Force, affect more than 44 million men age 50 and older who typically are candidates for a simple blood screen call the prostate-specific antigen (P.S.A.) test.

headline.main: What the Recommendations Mean for Men
